name: PCL-5
introduce:
**Hello there! ðŸ˜Š**   

**What's the DSM-5 (PCL-5) questionnaire?**    

The PTSD Checklist for DSM-5 (PCL-5) is a self-report rating scale for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms. It's often used by mental health professionals to help diagnose PTSD. The PCL-5 consists of 20 items that correspond to the DSM-5 criteria for PTSD.  

**Instruction:** Each item is rated on a 5-point scale (0-4: Not at all to Extremely) for how much the respondent has been bothered by that particular symptom over the past month.  

After completing the questionnaire, you will receive a score and the follow-up that can help you and healthcare professionals determine if you might benefit from further evaluation or treatment for your PTSD.  

If you believe you may have PTSD, it's important to seek help from a qualified mental health professional who can administer the PCL-5 and provide a proper diagnosis and treatment plan. Self-assessment tools can be a helpful starting point, but they are not a substitute for professional evaluation.  

 **Times:** 7 min  
  **Number of questions:** 20 

**Before we begin the PTSD screening using the DSM-5 (PCL-5) questionnaire, are you ready to start the survey?**

report.title: DSM-5(PCL-5) Score Report
report.description: All responses are summed to calculate the total DSM-5(PCL-5) score. Scores range from 0â€“80 with increasing scores indicating greater severity of symptoms of PTSD.

severities.description: This indicates minimal or no symptoms of PTSD.
This suggests mild symptoms of PTSD, which may or may not significantly impact daily functioning.
This is indicative of moderate symptoms of PTSD, which may have a moderate impact on daily functioning.
This suggests moderately severe symptoms of PTSD, which are likely to have a significant impact on daily life and functioning.
This indicates severe symptoms of PTSD, which are likely to have a severe impact on daily functioning and quality of life.

questions.question: Question 1: In the past month, how much were you bothered by repeated, disturbing, and unwanted memories of the stressful experience?
questions.description: This question assesses the presence of intrusive memories, which is a common symptom of PTSD.
questions.instruction: Please select the option that best fits your experience in the past month.

questions.question: Question 2: In the past month, how much were you bothered by repeated, disturbing dreams of the stressful experience?
questions.description: This question is designed to evaluate the occurrence of distressing dreams related to the traumatic event, which is another symptom of PTSD.
questions.instruction: Please select the option that best describes your experience over the past month.

questions.question: Question 3: In the past month, how much were you bothered by suddenly feeling or acting as if the stressful experience were actually happening again (as if you were actually back there reliving it)?
questions.description: This question aims to assess the experience of flashbacks, where it feels as though the traumatic event is occurring again.
questions.instruction: Please choose the option that most accurately reflects your experience in the past month.

questions.question: Question 4: In the past month, how much were you bothered by feeling very upset when something reminded you of the stressful experience?
questions.description: This question evaluates the intensity of emotional distress triggered by reminders of the traumatic event, which is a symptom of PTSD.
questions.instruction: Please select the option that best describes your level of distress in response to such reminders over the past month.

questions.question: Question 5: In the past month, how much were you bothered by having strong physical reactions (e.g., heart pounding, trouble breathing, sweating) when something reminded you of the stressful experience?
questions.description: This question is intended to measure physiological reactions to reminders of the trauma, which are physical symptoms of PTSD.
questions.instruction: Please choose the option that best represents your physical reactions in the past month when reminded of the stressful experience.

questions.question: Question 6: In the past month, how much were you bothered by avoiding memories, thoughts, or feelings related to the stressful experience?
questions.description: This question assesses the avoidance of internal reminders of the traumatic event, which is a common coping mechanism in PTSD.
questions.instruction: Please select the option that best describes your experience with avoidance in the past month.

questions.question: Question 7: In the past month, how much were you bothered by avoiding external reminders (people, places, conversations, activities, objects, situations) of the stressful experience?
questions.description: This question is designed to evaluate the extent to which you have been avoiding things that remind you of the traumatic event, which is another avoidance symptom of PTSD.
questions.instruction: Please select the option that best fits your experience with avoidance of external reminders over the past month.

questions.question: Question 8: In the past month, how much were you bothered by trouble remembering important parts of the stressful experience?
questions.description: This question assesses potential difficulties with memory, specifically regarding the traumatic event, which can be a symptom of PTSD.
questions.instruction: Please choose the option that most accurately reflects any memory issues you've experienced in the past month related to the stressful experience.

questions.question: Question 9: In the past month, how much were you bothered by having strong negative beliefs about yourself, others, or the world (e.g., having thoughts such as: I am bad, there is something seriously wrong with me, no one can be trusted, the world is completely dangerous)?
questions.description: This question aims to identify negative changes in beliefs and feelings that may arise after experiencing a traumatic event, which are symptoms associated with PTSD.
questions.instruction: Please select the option that best describes your experience with such negative beliefs in the past month.

questions.question: Question 10: In the past month, how much were you bothered by blaming yourself or someone else for the stressful experience or what happened after it?
questions.description: This question explores feelings of guilt or blame that may be associated with the traumatic event, which can be part of the emotional response in PTSD.
questions.instruction: Please choose the option that best represents your experience with self-blame or blaming others in relation to the stressful experience over the past month.

questions.question: Question 11: In the past month, how much were you bothered by negative feelings like fear, horror, anger, guilt, or shame?
questions.description: This question is intended to measure the range of negative emotions that can be triggered by the traumatic event, which are common emotional symptoms of PTSD.
questions.instruction: Please select the option that best describes the intensity of these negative feelings you've experienced in the past month.

questions.question: Question 12: In the past month, how much were you bothered by loss of interest in activities that you used to enjoy?
questions.description: This question assesses changes in your interest or participation in activities since the traumatic event, which can be an indication of the numbing or withdrawal symptoms associated with PTSD.
questions.instruction: Please choose the option that most accurately reflects any changes in your interest in activities over the past month.

questions.question: Question 13: In the past month, how much were you bothered by feeling distant or cut off from other people?
questions.description: This question is designed to evaluate feelings of detachment or estrangement from others, which can be a symptom of PTSD.
questions.instruction: Please select the option that best describes your experience with feeling disconnected from others in the past month.

questions.question: Question 14: In the past month, how much were you bothered by trouble experiencing positive feelings (for example, being unable to feel happiness or have loving feelings for people close to you)?
questions.description: This question aims to identify difficulties in experiencing positive emotions, which can be an aspect of the emotional numbing seen in PTSD.
questions.instruction: Please choose the option that best represents your experience with having trouble feeling positive emotions in the past month.

questions.question: Question 15: In the past month, how much were you bothered by feeling irritable or having angry outbursts (with little or no provocation)?
questions.description: This question assesses symptoms of irritability and anger, which are common in individuals with PTSD.
questions.instruction: Please select the option that best describes your experience with irritability or anger in the past month.

questions.question: Question 16: In the past month, how much were you bothered by taking too many risks or doing things that could cause you harm?
questions.description: This question is intended to measure reckless or self-destructive behavior, which can be a symptom of PTSD.
questions.instruction: Please choose the option that most accurately reflects any risky or harmful behaviors you've engaged in over the past month.

questions.question: Question 17: In the past month, how much were you bothered by being "super alert" or watchful or on guard?
questions.description: This question evaluates symptoms of hypervigilance, which involve being excessively alert or on edge, often seen in individuals with PTSD.
questions.instruction: Please select the option that best describes your experience with feeling overly alert or watchful in the past month.

questions.question: Question 18: In the past month, how much were you bothered by feeling jumpy or easily startled (for example, when someone walks up behind you)?
questions.description: This question assesses the symptom of an exaggerated startle response, which is a common reaction in individuals with PTSD.
questions.instruction: Please choose the option that best represents how often you've felt jumpy or easily startled in the past month.

questions.question: Question 19: In the past month, how much were you bothered by having difficulty concentrating?
questions.description: This question is designed to measure concentration difficulties, which can be a symptom of PTSD.
questions.instruction: Please select the option that best describes your experience with concentration problems in the past month.

questions.question: Question 20: In the past month, how much were you bothered by trouble falling or staying asleep?
questions.description: This final question assesses sleep disturbances, which are common in individuals with PTSD.
questions.instruction:
Please choose the option that most accurately reflects any difficulties you've had with sleep over the past month.  

After you answer this question, we will calculate and present your final score.
